title: HPHT Operations
description: High Pressure High Temperature drilling requires specialized procedures, equipment, and decision-making. This module covers the unique challenges of HPHT environments where margins are tight and consequences of error are severe.
objectives: Understand HPHT classification and equipment requirements
Manage operations within narrow mud weight windows
Recognize and respond to HPHT-specific hazards
Apply heightened well control alertness protocols

keyTopics.content: HPHT wells are classified by temperature and pressure thresholds. Tier 1: >300째F or >10,000 psi. Tier 2: >350째F or >15,000 psi. Tier 3: >400째F or >20,000 psi. Classification drives equipment ratings, material selection, and operational procedures.

In HPHT formations, pore pressure and fracture gradient converge, leaving minimal operating margin. A 1.3 ppg window (like Phoenix-702 at TD) means every 0.1 ppg matters. ECD must be precisely managed - too low risks a kick, too high risks losses.

Maximum Anticipated Wellhead Pressure may approach or exceed BOP ratings in extreme HPHT. When MAWP exceeds equipment limits, prevention becomes the primary barrier - you cannot rely on shut-in. Early kick detection and MPD become mandatory, not optional.

High temperatures affect mud properties (thinning, barite sag), elastomers (BOP seals), electronics (MWD/LWD), and personnel (heat stress in enclosed spaces). Mud rheology measured at surface differs from downhole behavior.

Limited kick tolerance is the defining challenge. With tight windows, even small influxes risk exceeding formation strength at the shoe. Conventional well kill may not be viable for larger kicks - pre-planned alternatives (bullheading, volumetric) must be ready.

referenceWellContext.tdWindow: 17.2 ppg PP / 18.5 ppg FG = 1.3 ppg margin

operationalPrinciples: Prevention over intervention - avoid kicks rather than rely on killing them
Continuous monitoring - PWD, flow, pit volume at highest sensitivity
Pre-planned responses - know your alternatives before you need them
Crew competency - everyone understands the elevated risk level
Equipment verification - confirm ratings match well conditions
